Law Top Colleges In India
Updated on May 6, 2024 14:49 IST

Aneena Aley Abraham

Top Law Colleges in India 2024: Rank, Fees, Courses, Admission, Cutoff

India is home to almost 1,500 best universities for Law. Among these, 27 are top Law colleges in India. Out of which 18 colleges are government owned and 9 colleges are private, which provide UG, PG law courses in a full-time and part-time mode of study. The best Law colleges in India are NLSIU Bangalore, NLU Delhi, Nalsar University of Law, NLU Kolkata, Faculty of Law, JMI, Symbiosis Law School, GNLU Gandhinagar, SOA, BBAU Lucknow, Saveetha Institute of Medical and Technical Sciences. CLAT, CUET and LSAT India are the popular entrance exam for admission to top 10 LLM colleges in India.

Latest Update:

  • LSAT India 2024 exam for the May session will be held between May 16, 2024 to May 19, 2024.

  • CLAT Round 3 cutoff is out for 5-year integrated LLB (UG) and one-year LLM (PG) courses. The last date for final Payment of the University Fee is May 14, 2024. Further, CNLU will release the CLAT Round 4 on May 20, 2024.
  • The Consortium of NLUs has also released the CLAT 2024 Counselling schedule.

Law is a career stream that aspirants can pursue at the Undergraduate (UG), Postgraduate (PG), or Doctorate (PhD) level to study, research, and practice in India. Best Law Colleges in India: Admissions 2024

For admission to law courses, eligibility criteria may vary depending on the institution and the specific course. Given below are the basic eligibility criteria that candidates need to fulfill for admission to UG and PG Law courses.

UG (Integrated-LLB)

  • Candidates must pass Class 10+2 in any stream with a minimum of 45 per cent aggregate from a recognised board.
  • There is no age bar.

UG (LLB)

  • Candidates must have completed their graduation in any stream with at least 45% marks (40% for SC/ST/PwD candidates) from a recognised university. 
  • There is no age bar.

PG (LLM)

  • Candidates must have completed LLB or an equivalent examination with at least 50% marks from a recognised university.
  • There is no age bar.

Disclaimer: This information is sourced from the official website and may vary.

Popular Entrance Exams Accepted by Best Law Colleges in India

For admissions to best law colleges in India, Candidates must qualify for some of the popular exams and they are:

  • CLAT: The national-level Common Law Admission Test (or CLAT) is conducted by the Consortium of NLUs for admission to 5-year integrated LLB (UG) and one-year LLM (PG) courses. All the seats of NLUs will be filled on the basis of CLAT 2023 reservation criteria as defined by the consortium.
  • CUET: CUET stands for Central University Entrance Test. It is an all-India level entrance exam conducted by NTA for admission to UG courses offered in all the participating institutions. The exam is conducted in a computer-based mode for two hours. Originally CUCET was conducted by UGC in paper-pencil-based mode.
  • LSAT India: Law School Admission Test India is a national-level entrance exam conducted by the Law School Admission Council for admission to various law courses.
  • AILET: All India Law Entrance Test is a national-level entrance exam conducted by National Law University Delhi (NLU Delhi) for admission to BALLB, LLM, etc.
  • AMU Entrance Exam: Aligarh Muslim University Entrance Exam is a national-level entrance exam conducted by Aligarh Muslim University for admission to various courses at AMU.

Types of Law Schools in India

In India, there are primarily two kinds of Law colleges:

  • National Law Universities (NLUs): These are autonomous, public universities established by an Act of Parliament of the Government of India. In India, there are currently 23 NLUs, which are widely regarded as the premier legal institutions in the country. Top law firms and corporations are eager to hire graduates from NLU or the top Law government colleges in India.
  • Other Law Colleges: These consist of universities that provide legal programmes, private law colleges, and government law institutions. These colleges range widely in quality, with some being quite good. They are not, however, as esteemed as the NLUs in general.

In addition to the different types of law colleges, there are different types of law degrees offered in India. The most popular undergraduate legal degree is the three-year Bachelor of Laws (LLB) programme. Additionally, there are integrated five-year programmes that combine an LLB with an undergraduate degree. The Master of Laws (LLM) and the Doctor of Philosophy in Law (PhD) are examples of postgraduate legal degrees.

Disclaimer: This information is sourced from official website and may vary.

Inspection by BCI for Top Law Colleges in India

An important factor in guaranteeing the caliber of legal education in India is the Bar Council of India (BCI). Although the BCI is not actively involved in evaluating and clearing specific law colleges, it does have a thorough procedure for examining, approving, and guaranteeing that already existing law colleges uphold specific requirements.

  • Establishing Standards

Through Schedule IV and its Rules on Legal Education, the BCI establishes the minimal requirements for legal education. These include aspects like standard curriculum, faculty, student-teacher ratio, infrastructure and amenities.

  • Approval of New Law Colleges

Any newly established law school that wants to offer an LLB programme must apply to the BCI for approval. This includes outlining the description of faculty, staff, programme, and other specifications of the college. BCI levies inspection fees for dispatching a team to evaluate the college and confirm whether the college satisfies the requirements.  

  • Inspection of Existing Law Colleges

BCI examines student records, curricular materials, teachers' credentials, amenities provided by the college etc. and conducts student-teacher interviews to evaluate the standard of education.

  • Repercussions for Non-Compliance

The Council may take several measures in case a law college does not satisfy the BCI criteria, such as issuing warnings or directives to ensure compliance, imposing penalties and fines and may also result in withdrawing approval for the college.

FAQs Top Law Colleges in India

Q. How many top Law colleges are there in India?

A. There are about 1,500 Law colleges in India. Among these, 30 are Top Ranked Law colleges in India. Out of which 18 colleges are Public and 9 are Private. Some of the popular colleges are National Law School of India Bangalore, NLU Delhi, Nalsar University of Law, Symbiosis Law School Pune, NLU Kolkata, Faulty of Law Jamia Millia Islamia, GNLU Gandhinagar and many more. 

Q. What is the eligibility criteria of Top Ranked Law colleges in India?

A. The eligibility criteria for Law programmes vary depending on the course-level. Given below is the basic eligibility criteria that candidates need to fulfil for admission to UG and PG Law courses. UG Law Courses Eligibility (LLB)

  • Candidates must clear graduation in any stream with minimum 45-50 per cent aggregate
  • There is no age bar

PG Law Courses Eligibility (LLM)

  • Candidates must possess an LLB degree
  • There is no age bar

Q. Which are the most popular ranked Law colleges in India based on placements?

Q. Are there any job opportunities for students who pursue Law courses in India?

A. Yes, there are several job opportunities for Law students. Some of them are listed below:

  • Lawyer
  • Legal Advisors
  • Judges
  • Solicitors
  • Legal Executives
  • Notary Public
  • Oath Commissioner

Q. Which city has the maximum top ranked Law colleges in India?

A. Law is a popular course choice among candidates aspiring to become lawyers in India. Candidates can pursue a Law graduation course after Class 12 or obtain a bachelors degree. Those wanting to pursue the course after Class 12 need to enroll in five-year integrated-LLB programmes such as BA LLB, BBA LLB, BSc LLB and BTech LLB. Those who wish to pursue Law after graduation can enroll in LLB courses of three years duration. The post-graduation degree in Law is known as LLM. There are almost 30 Top Ranked Law colleges in India. Out of which, Delhi has the maximum Top Ranked Law colleges in India.

Q. Which Law College has the highest fees?

A. Yes, it is estimated that studying Law in India is slightly expensive. As, 16 colleges have their annual fee ranging > INR 5 lakh and some of them are:

College Name Course Fees
NLSIU Bangalore 13.45 lakh
NLU Delhi 6.75 Lakh
Symbiosis Law School 8.25 Lakh
Nalsar University of Law 7.95 Lakh

  • Faculty of Law, Jamia Milia Islamia
  • Guru Gobind Singh Indraprastha University
  • Amity University Gurugram
